why: Moving with control and awareness improves outcomes more than sheer volume.

slides.title: Movement Optimism
slides.content: Greg Lehman's approach: the body has amazing ability to adapt to different positions and stresses - there's no single 'correct' way to move.

slides.title: Quality vs. Quantity
slides.content: Focus on movement that feels good and pain-free rather than chasing perfect form or high volume - respect your body's natural adaptations.

slides.title: Individual Variability
slides.content: Factors like foot pronation are natural load-absorbing mechanisms, not flaws to fix - embrace your body's unique movement patterns.

slides.title: Adaptive Capacity
slides.content: The body is resilient and can adapt to different stresses without inherent risk - movement quality means working with your body, not against it.

slides.title: Myth vs Fact
slides.content: Myth: More reps = better. Fact: Better reps = better.

slides.title: Try this today
slides.content: Film one set; score control 1â€“5; repeat set slower with steadier breath.
slides.resourceLabel: Listen: Greg Lehman on Movement Optimism
